entry.title: 销售订单号码段灵活编码
entry.content:
业务需求

使用可配置参数和公式（CPF）框架，作为配置专家的您可以定义新创建销售凭证号码段规则。这些规则能够实现销售凭证到编号范围区间的灵活分配，并可选择性地配置编号范围前缀。

配置总览

系统配置

1. SSCUI: 103283 Define Number Range Prefixes for Sales Documents

2. SSCUI: 102819 Define Number Ranges for Sales Documents

注意：自定义销售订单号码段不支持外部编码，欢迎有外部编码需求的客户提CIP.

3. SSCUI: 104014 Define Formulas for Flexible Sales Document Numbering

我这里用的案例是：公司代码1310+订单原因006（实惠价格）= 编码前缀CN+编码范围区间01

4. SSCUI：104015 Define Custom Routines for Flexible Sales Document Numbering

5. SSCUI: 103823 Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types 

系统实现

创建销售订单售达方输入公司1310的客户，订单原因输入006实惠价格，保存后销售订单编码为CN0000001

感谢观看

entry.title: Support of Working Day Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Background

A Working Day, also known as Business Day or Factory Day, is an official work day. And the working day calendar, if compared with standard calendar, it will exclude the weekends (Saturday and Sunday) together with national holidays.

In SAP Analytics Cloud, there will be some activities need to be scheduled in a recursive way, such as a daily work, a weekly or bi-weekly work. In the past, these activities can be planned using the standard calendar. But the standard calendar can not differentiate between a working day or a non-working day. As a consequence, some un-necessary tasks will be activated and lead to additional house-keeping effort.

Starting from QRC4 2025, working day calendar is now supported in SAP Analytics Cloud. User can now define recurrence settings using a working day calendar. Series based on working day calendars will have no occurrences on non-working days.

How to set up a working day calendar

Before use the working day calendar in the recurrence settings, a working day calendar needs to be defined in advance. Customers need to define their own working day calendars, since different regions may have their own working day calendars. This can be achieved by defining a Date dimension as User-Managed instead of System-Managed dimension. Because by defining a user-managed data dimension, user can add additional properties to that date dimension and use those properties to indicate whether it is a working day or non-working day.

User can create a new property like the below screenshot:

Please make sure the property ID is started with "CAL_WORKING_DAY_" so the system will recognize this property as working day calendar. And then maintain the property for each member. 1 for working days and 0 for non-working days.

 

Customers may ask, does that mean I should modify the Date dimension for all my existing models?

The answer is NO. The related recurrence setting will allow user to select a working day calendar from a different model. This means, user can create a model with working day calendar defined, and reuse that model in different scenarios and related models. Although custom can use an existing model and enhance the date dimension accordingly, but it could be more convenient to create a brand-new model, so the working calendar can be managed centrally without impact existing models. And there's another reason to define a brand-new model. Since reading the working day calendar information from the model will still follow the data access control as a standard model object. A brand-new model under public folder will avoid additional effort for authentication configuration.

For more details about how to set up a working day calendar in a model, please check the related help document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-a-working-day-calendar-in-a-model

 

How to use the working day calendar for your series

Currently, the working day calendar can be used in the recurrence setting, which is used in some features, including:

Calendar task, Schedule Publication, Data Change Insight.

Using Calendar task as an example, when create a task which needs to be recursive, the option to use working day calendar will be available.

As shown in the above screenshot, user can set the recurrence patten and select the desired days for working days. User will be able to choose the corresponding model and property created in advance.

If the recurrence pattern is set to week or month, the working day calendar is also available with similar behavior.

Besides the recurrent setting in task design, the working day calendar can also be used in the calendar list view.

In the Gantt Chart Settings, user can also enable showing the calendar with working day calendar.

Once this setting is turned on, the gantt chart display will display the non-working days in grey if there's at least one event loaded in the calendar.

For more details about how to set up recurrence using working day calendar, please check the below online document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-recurrence-using-a-working-day-calendar

The settings for Schedule Publication and Data Change Insight will be similar.

You may also check the below demo video as reference.

 

If the above video doesn't work, you may also check it via below link:

https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_byk63fen

 

Thanks a lot and let us know if you have any questions or comments.

best regards, Roy

entry.title: Joule 事务性能力解析：优化SAP S/4HANA Cloud开票流程
entry.content:
Joule在10月份的更新中，为SAP S/4HANA Cloud公有云版本的开票职员（Billing Clerk）处理日常开票任务带来了全新的事务性能力。这一创新将原本需要在多个应用间切换、手动输入数据的复杂流程，转化为集中高效的对话式操作，提升了处理效率。

自动化识别与快速处理：消除手动输入负担

对开票职员来说，日常处理单个开票凭证时，手动指定复杂的凭证编号既耗时又容易出错。

Joule通过以下方式简化了这一流程： Joule能够自动识别并填充来自目标开票凭证对象页面的凭证编号，用户无需在命令中手动指定。当用户进入需要处理的开票凭证页面后，只需启动Joule并发出简单指令即可。 这一自动识别功能支持用户快速执行关键任务：

  • 直接过账开票凭证：用户可以使用简短的请求，如“过账开票凭证”（Post billing document）或“过账凭证”（Post bd）。
  • 直接更改开票日期：用户可以通过对话请求更改日期，例如“更改开票日期至今天”（Change billing date to today）或指定具体日期，例如“更改开票日期至 2025 年 5 月 15 日”（Change billing date to May 15, 2025）。

高效解决过账问题：集中化诊断与修复

Joule的核心价值体现在对“卡住的”开票凭证的集成处理能力上，即那些因过账问题无法成功过账到财务会计系统的凭证。Joule提供了一套完整的解决方案：

  1. 查找与筛选问题凭证

用户可以指令Joule显示因过账问题无法过账的开票凭证。为获得最佳结果，建议用户始终从查找有问题的凭证开始操作。 用户可以通过指定详细的筛选条件来缩小搜索范围，例如：SD文档类别、开票凭证类型、问题类型、公司代码、销售组织或分销渠道等。

示例指令如：“显示问题类型为“会计访问”且开票凭证类型为 F2, CI01 的凭证”（Show billing documents with posting issue type Accounting Access, of billing document types F2, CI01）。

  1. 诊断与解决会计访问错误

Joule专注于解决当相关过账期间已关闭时发生的会计访问错误（如F5/286和F5/903错误），能够指导开票职员逐步解决这些错误。

  1. 修正日期并重新过账

如果诊断发现会计访问错误是由于开票凭证日期超出开放过账期间，用户可直接在Joule中执行修复：

  • 更改开票日期：用户可在聊天中要求设置新日期，或使用Joule提供的“Change Billing Date to Today”快速按钮。将开票日期更改为落入开放过账期间内的日期，即可有效解决会计访问错误 。
  • 重新过账：错误修复后，Joule会自动再次过账开票凭证。用户也可通过聊天命令或列表卡中的“Post”按钮手动过账。每次操作仅能过账单个凭证 。

请点击以下链接查看在Joule中简化billing功能的演示：

 Process Billing Documents with Posting Issues in Joule_SimpleVersion

 前提条件

要使用Joule的开票能力，在确保了Joule的开通和配置后，用户必须拥有分配了Sales - Billing Documents (SAP_SD_BC_BIL_DOC_PC) 业务目录的业务角色。默认情况下，Billing Clerk (SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK) 业务角色模板已包含此业务目录。

请查看往期blog了解更多Joule的基础功能以及如何开通免费的BASE AI包开始使用Joule。

Joule功能全景介绍：Joule在SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition... - SAP Community

即刻免费解锁：SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 基础 AI 包 (B... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: IAS User Mail
entry.content:
For both types of users account activation emails may be sent by IAS.
The question is whether this is desired for users from Azure(Entra): likely the authenticating IdP for these users is Entra and so it is not required run through account confirmation and setting of local credentials in IAS. However if desired it can be configured like this and 'On behalf'  will be the relevant email template.
For users registered in IAS it depends whether they register themselves or will be created by an admin. 'Self registration' or 'Invitation' and for users created by an admin 'On-behalf Registration' email template will be the relevant one.
Which mail server is used is a different question: if nothing is configured, IAS uses default mail server - see also https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/configure-mail-server-for-application-processes

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2026
entry.content:
One of the benefits of using SAP BTP ABAP Environment is that updates and upgrades are applied by SAP to the systems in quite a high frequency and close to the corresponding release time.
Find the latest known schedule of Major Upgrade Windows and Weekly Maintenance Windows for 2026 in this blog post.

 

Major Upgrade Windows

As in 2025, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment will have 4 Major Upgrade Windows in 2026. These 24 hours of potential system unavailability are used to upgrade the systems to the next major version.
The events for the Major Upgrade Windows are harmonized between all SAP Cloud Products and scheduled for the following weekends:

  • February 14th – 15th (Release 2602)
  • May 16th – 17th (Release 2605)
  • August 15th – 16th (Release 2608)
  • November 14th – 15th (Release 2611)

Depending on the data center region, the 24 hours downtime will start/end at:

  • MENA: FRI 1 am - SAT 1 am UTC
  • APJ: FRI 9 pm – SAT 9 pm UTC
  • Europe: SAT 4 am – SUN 4 am UTC
  • Americas: SAT 10 am – SUN 10 am UTC

Please find the release schedule of the referenced UI5 versions in this blog post.

 

Weekly Maintenance Windows

Potentially every weekend, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment could use a downtime of 4 hours, to apply SAP HANA Cloud updates, Hotfix Collections and other changes.
Depending on the data center region, the 4 hours downtime may start at:

  • MENA: FRI 5 pm UTC
  • APJ: SAT 2 pm UTC
  • Europe: SAT 9 pm UTC
  • Americas: SUN 5 am UTC

The planned schedule for Hotfix Collection imports after upgrade to release 2602 will be published by end of December.

 

Reduction of Planned Maintenance Windows

We introduced Downtime-optimized Upgrades and Hotfix Collection Imports for Production with release 2502. For the next steps about the Reduction of Planned Maintenance Windows for HFC Imports and Upgrades see our roadmap.

 

Prepare for 2602: Cloud Foundry CLI and CAPI

Starting with release 2602, the service broker for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment will switch to asynchronous processing for service binding and service key creation requests. This change will impact client applications using interfaces like the CF CLI and CAPI. Refer to Service Key and Service Bindings Requests will change to asynchronous processing for more details.

 

Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS)

Please register to Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS) in SAP for Me to get important information about planned and unplanned downtimes:

  • Access to Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS): https://me.sap.com/systemsprovisioning/getNotified
  • Find more information about Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS) in this documentation
  • To find the SAP BTP ABAP Environment entry select:
    Cloud Service: SAP BTP ABAP environment
    Solution Area: SAP Build

 

References

  • Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows for SAP Cloud Services
  • SAP Note 2888562 – Intelligent Enterprise Suite: Harmonized release calendar for SAP Cloud products
  • Service Level Agreement for SAP Cloud Services

entry.title: Public Cloud - Debit/Credit Shift Between FSV Nodes - API or CDS view
entry.content:
Dear all,

We are currently working on a project in which the business intelligence functionality is handled in an external system. As part of this setup, we transfer financial data — such as assets and liabilities — to that system, and the Debit/Credit Shift Between FSV Nodes is activated.

However, for the accounts where this function is enabled, we do not receive any information indicating whether the journal entry was posted to an asset or liability account. We have not been able to retrieve this information through any available API or CDS view, nor have we found a way to automatically identify which accounts are flagged for the shift within the hierarchy.

We kindly request your support in identifying how this information can be retrieved.

Kind regards,
William

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Central Business Configuration 2509 FD1
entry.content:
With the latest release for SAP Central Business Configuration, an exciting new feature is available. This blog post will provide you with a concise overview.

Merging Business Configuration Enhancements Directly

For those familiar with SAP Central Business Configuration, the parallel line feature is a powerful tool. It allows you to make business configuration enhancements and test them in a secure environment without affecting your daily operations. Once you’ve made all changes in the parallel line, you perform the rebase operation to make sure any changes made in the main line in the meantime are included and that there are no conflicting values. Then, you merge your changes back to the main line and deploy them to your productive system.

Previously, the merge operation was initiated through a support case. To simplify and accelerate this process, you can now directly merge changes without needing to create a support case. This improvement not only saves time but also allows you to respond even faster to evolving business requirements.

Merge option in the Settings app

For a quick summary, check out this video about What's New in 2509 FD1. Don’t forget to also use the What’s New Viewer on the SAP Help Portal, which provides further details and links about all the recent changes.

That wraps up the new features this time. Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

Do you have any ideas on how to further enhance SAP Central Business Configuration? Go to the Customer Influence platform to submit an improvement request or vote for the ideas of others. This helps us understand your requirements even better and prioritize our work accordingly. We’re looking forward to your improvement requests.

entry.title: How do you work with Story reporting and PM Forms ? (and the Guardrails...)
entry.content:
Hi,

We are just starting with Story reporting, and I find that when working with Performance Management data, I very quickly hit the Guardrails warnings (even though I use 7 tables, 12 columns).

How can you make some decent reporting with data across so many different tables with such a limit ?

My example, on a 360 multirater report. We are a company of 6000 employees (so not a big SAP client in the sense of employee numbers). We run a 360 on all our 800 managers, rated by a total of 6000 employees on 13 questions. Using some demographic columns, I am maxing out all the time with above 5 millions cells. 
I get the red "Failed to save the query. Please contact your administrator" error.
And when I try again the next day it seems to work again.

My current report project, is to create a simple dashboard with the Performance From status, same thing I am getting error messages.

I am not a reporting guru, I have developed dozens of old table reports in the legacy reports, I was hoping that this Story would open up to some highly creative and flashy results, but no. 

Happy to hear how others succeed with Story on PM Forms !

Thanks,

Kris

entry.title: Re: 999 – The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello Jack,

while the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field was first meant to only be used by the BAPI, we extended its use also to certain other dedicated processes called by the journal entry posting FIORI apps and the underlying ODATA services. So yes, the FIORI apps do not use the BAPIs, but this very FBDC_P060 tcode passes the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field to the ODATA service implementation (in header structure FDC_S_ACCDOC_HDR); the ODATA service implementation then calls the so-called accounting interface (functions AC_DOCUMENT_CREATE and AC_DOCUMENT_POST) and passes the EV_POSTNG_CTRL information in the header structure ACCHD. The ACCHD-EV_POSTNG_CTRL is then evaluated by the relevant BSEG summarization code (function group FACI, subroutine FI_DOCUMENT_COLLECT). Again: in this case, the summarization is not technically triggered by the BAdi, but by directly evaluating the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field. 

Please believe me, I implemented almost all of this myself 😉

Kind regards, 

Stefan

entry.title: Modern Enterprise Management with SAP: Key Capabilities, Use-Cases and AI-Enabled Integration
entry.content:
Modern Enterprise Management with SAP: Key Capabilities, Use-Cases and AI-Enabled Integration

1.   Introduction

Today’s companies face many pressures: complex global supply chains, changing staffing needs, customers who want instant service, and stricter rules and budgets. To handle this complexity, modern enterprise management systems (ERP) must do more than record transactions. They should provide real-time insights, connect processes from start to finish, and deliver smooth digital experiences for employees, customers, suppliers, and partners.

Different departments define “customer” in different ways. Depending on the team, the people they serve might be employees, partners, suppliers, finance teams, citizens, or shoppers. But they all have questions, problems, and requests that need to be resolved.

For many years, IT teams have used IT service management (ITSM) methods and tools to deliver and support IT services. Enterprise service management (ESM) takes these same service management ideas and applies them to other departments—like HR, customer service, finance, and procurement—to make their work simpler, more consistent, and more digital.

Key capabilities of an enterprise-management solution (SAP ESM)

Service catalog: A central list of every service each team offers, with clear descriptions and how to request them.

Service desk: One main help centre for questions, incidents, and requests, reachable by email, chat, SMS, or phone.

Self-service portal: An online place where people can find answers, submit requests, and track progress without calling support.

SLAs: Clear rules for how fast and how well services will be delivered, so expectations are set for everyone.

Automated, AI-enabled workflows: Automation and AI route requests to the right people and handle repeat tasks to speed things up and keep work consistent.

Knowledge base: A shared library of guides and solutions so people can quickly find what they need.

Reporting and analytics: Tools to measure performance, spot trends, and create reports for ongoing improvements and decisions.

Two example business scenarios-

HR: An employee requests leave or reports a workplace issue in the self-service portal. The request is automatically sent to the right HR staff, records are updated, and the employee gets notified when it’s done.

Finance/Customer–Vendor: A vendor submits an invoice through the portal. The system checks it, matches it to purchase orders, and routes it for approval. Finance can track status and fix issues quickly.

How integration across lines of business adds value :

SAP connects HR, finance, procurement, sales, and more so information flows smoothly across teams and systems.

Example: When HR approves leave or resolves a grievance, employee master data is updated automatically so payroll and scheduling stay correct.

This reduces errors, saves time, and ensures everyone is working with up-to-date information.

How built-in AI and automation enhance everything

  • AI and automation sort requests, send reminders, and analyze data to find trends, so routine work takes less time.
  • Teams can focus on higher-value tasks while the system keeps processes moving consistently.
  • AI can help predict issues and suggest fixes, making the organization more proactive and responsive.

In short, SAP ESM connects departments, streamlines work with automation and AI, and makes it easy for employees, customers, and partners to get what they need quickly

2. Business Scenarios: How it Works in Practice

Scenario A: HR / Workforce Flow – Leave Approval → Data Update → Grievance Management

Imagine an employee requests leave via a self-service portal. The manager approves via inbox, HR extracts insights, updates organizational and payroll master data, and subsequently a grievance arises (maybe a leave mix-up). Here’s how the platform supports:

  • Leave approval: In S/4HANA (or integrated HCM) the transactional app “Approve Leave Requests” enables managers to approve or reject leave requests for their direct reports.  
  • Core HR master-data update: The HR module supports recording of master employee data, organizational structure, time recording etc.  
  • Grievance / case-management: Through the Service Management (ESM) layer the employee’s case (e.g., grievance about leave calculation) can be logged, auto-classified, routed to the correct HR agent and resolved via knowledge-base/self-service. For example, the Help-Portal entry for ESM mentions automatic case creation, categorisation and routing.  
  • Integration: Because HR and the employee master data live in the same platform, updates triggered by the leave approval (for example, changed leave balance, change in cost centre or reporting line) can feed into downstream processes like payroll, time sheet, internal billing or cost-charging.
  • Insights & analytics: HR management gets dashboards showing leave utilisation trends, absence hotspots, grievance volumes by department; the same platform allows the HR team to monitor and act.
  • AI/automation: Using the HR-service solution, the AI copilot (for example Joule) can assist employees via chat or guided self-service for typical queries (“What is my available leave?”), auto-classify tickets (“leave balance grievance”) and assign to correct HR agent.  

Why this matters:

  • Employee experience improves: self-service, faster approvals, transparency.
  • HR efficiency increases: fewer manual tasks, faster resolution of cases, fewer errors in master data.
  • Master data integrity improves: because updates flow into a common model, downstream processes (payroll, cost-allocation) benefit.
  • Visibility and agility: HR leadership gains real-time visibility into workforce metrics.
  • Compliance & control: Processes are audited, controls can be embedded in workflows, data protection features included.

Scenario B: Customer / Vendor Financial Process – Customer Invoice Inquiry & Payment Advice Posting

Turning to the finance side and front-office/back-office interactions: Consider a vendor or customer calling the enterprise with an invoice status inquiry, or sending a payment advice which must be posted against the receivable ledger.

  • Accounts Receivable / Incoming invoice & payment: The capability-map shows that “Accounts Receivable” is part of Finance Operations in S/4HANA.  
  • Digital invoice processing: The blog on incoming-invoice-processing with S/4HANA describes scanning/email/EDI, automated data extraction (OCR/AI), workflow for approval, and posting once approved.  
  • Self-service & service-agent scenario: Under ESM, an agent desktop allows customer/supplier search, employee search, knowledge-base lookup and case routing for invoice or payment queries. The Feature-Scope for Enterprise Service Management lists entities like Customer, Supplier, Employee search in the agent desktop.  
  • Example use case: In the Leveraging ESM document, typical business user questions are “Why has my invoice been rejected?”, “Did you process the payment advice that I emailed you?”  

Process flow (customer invoice inquiry / payment advice):

  1. Customer calls or submits self-service ticket requesting invoice status.
  2. Service agent uses the ESM agent desktop: searches the business partner (customer), views open invoices, credit-holds, payment history (thanks to integration with FI/AR ledger).
  3. If payment advice is received (e.g., via email), it may be scanned or imported, matched to customer account, auto-classified, posted or flagged if mismatched.
  4. If an exception (e.g., invoice rejected, credit-limit exceeded) is found, the case is automatically routed to the correct finance team for resolution.
  5. Customer receives notification/status update via portal. The underlying AR ledger is updated and dashboards reflect DSO (days sales outstanding) metrics, open items, aging, etc.
  6. AI/automation: the system can suggest resolutions (e.g., suggest posting location, note to agent “invoice has been posted automatically after validation”), summarise case history, extract entity info from the payment advice document.

Why this matters:

  • Enhances customer / vendor experience via faster resolution and transparency.
  • Reduces finance servicing cost (less manual lookup, fewer escalations).
  • Improves working capital (faster cash-application, fewer outstanding items).
  • Provides analytics for finance leadership (clear view of receivables, credit-holds, aging trends).
  • Improves collaboration between front-office (service/call-centre) and back-office (finance ledger) because both operate in the same integrated platform.

3. Integration Across Lob’s – Making the “Enterprise” in Enterprise Management

The power of these platforms truly lies in integration: not just modules working separately, but data, workflows and services crossing boundaries.

Examples of integrated flows:

  • HR → Finance: When an employee changes cost-centre or department (via HR master-data update), this automatically triggers updates to financial cost-allocations or internal billing (if relevant).
  • HR → Service: An employee raises a grievance, the HR service-management module routes it, captures resolution, updates master-data or organisational info (e.g., manager changed).
  • Finance → Service/Customer: Invoices or payment issues raised by customers trigger service-cases; the service-agent has direct access to financial ledger data (via ESM agent desktop) and resolves faster.
  • Procurement/Payables → Finance: Vendor invoices (procure-to-pay) feed into the accounts-payable ledger and analytics on vendor-performance, cash-timing, discount capture.
  • Analytics/Insights: Because all data resides in one system (e.g., SAP HANA in S/4HANA), cross-domain reporting (HR + Finance + Procurement) is possible (for example, cost of workforce + overtime + cost centre budget + vendor spend).

Why integration matters:

  • Eliminates silos → faster information flow, fewer manual hand-offs.
  • Improves data accuracy (one source of truth) → better decision making.
  • Enables process automation across domains → lower cost, faster turnaround.
  • Enables better insights across functions → e.g., linking workforce absenteeism trends (HR) with customer satisfaction/service performance (Service) or cost impact (Finance).

4. Built-In AI and Automation – The “Next” in Next-Gen ERP

As enterprises evolve, simply digitising legacy processes isn’t enough – smart automation, AI-driven insights and prescriptive analytics become differentiators.

  • The HR service-management solution emphasises “AI-driven case management, auto-classification, case summarisation, emails, recommendations” via the AI copilot “Joule”.  
  • The invoice processing emphasises “automated document processing, machine-learning components , Business data extraction and validation , autoflow / posting automation.”  
  • For service-management features “automatic case creation, categorisation, prioritisation, and routing to the right agent.”  

Keyways AI & Automation add value:

  • Document-intake automation: invoices, payment advices, leave requests, grievance tickets – reduce manual effort and errors.
  • Self-service guidance: employees, customers or vendors get faster answers via chatbots, guided flows, intelligent suggestions.
  • Predictive analytics & alerts: e.g., an employee’s leave pattern may trigger a burnout risk alert; ageing receivables may suggest follow-up action.
  • Workflow automation: automatic routing, escalations, posting of transactions once validations pass, all leveraging pre-built rules + AI suggestion.
  • Agent enablement: service agents or HR/finance staff get summarised case history, recommended next steps, machine-suggested resolution or content references.
  • Continuous improvement: analytics on process bottlenecks, service resolution times, invoice-processing metrics feed into improvement loops.

5. Why Enterprises Should Care (And Some Practical Tips)

For enterprises (whether large domestic-players, MNC local units, or global captives), the above capabilities translate into concrete business value:

  • Dealing with highly dynamic work-forces, regulatory compliance (labour laws, tax, GST, data protection) means HR and Finance need modernisation.
  • Customers/venders expect digital interactions (portals, status updates, query resolution) – service management integrated with finance/back-office becomes differentiator.
  • Global operations (multi-currency, multi-entity) demand real-time consolidation, simplified data structure (HANA) and embedded analytics.
  • Cost pressures: automation (AI, workflows) helps reduce operational cost of servicing, approvals, invoice handling, grievances.
  • Insight‐driven decisions: linking workforce costs + customer service + vendor payments + supply-chain gives competitive edge.

Practical tips for implementation:

  • Start with end-to-end scenario definition rather than isolated modules: e.g., define your leave-to-pay flow, or your invoice-to-cash and query resolution flow.
  • Ensure master data integrity: business partner, employee, vendor/customer data needs to be clean.
  • Use pre-built services/workflows (Fiori apps, Flexible Workflow, Inbox, case-management templates) rather than custom build where possible.
  • Leverage the AI/automation capabilities early: for example document-processing for invoices; self-service for HR queries.
  • Integrate across LoBs: not just HR or Finance alone. For example, ensure HR updates (cost-centres, org-structure) feed into Finance, or ensure customer-query handling has ledger visibility to resolve faster.
  • Focus on process performance metrics: invoice-cycle time, DSO, case-first-response-time, employee self-service adoption, etc. Use the analytics platform built into the ERP to measure and improve.
  • Pay attention to change management: Employees, service-agents, managers must adapt to new self-service apps, mobile approvals, chatbots, new workflows.

Conclusion

In today’s digital economy, enterprise management is no longer about simply capturing transactions and running reports. It’s about connecting people, processes and data, enabling end-to-end flows across HR, Finance, Service, Procurement and Sales, and injecting intelligence and automation to accelerate and simplify operations.

Platforms like SAP S/4HANA, combined with enterprise-service-management layers, provide the breadth, depth and modern architecture to deliver these capabilities. From leave request to master-data update to grievance resolution, or from customer invoice query to payment advice posting to ledger update – the integrated, intelligent enterprise becomes possible.

For enterprises embracing these capabilities is not just IT-modernisation — it’s a business-transformation lever: faster service, lower cost, better insight, more agility. If your organisation is onto the next wave of digital readiness, this is your architecture.

entry.title: Error: Dropping tables is not supported (in artifact:“my.bookshop.Books”)
entry.content:
I am working on my first CAP application (apart from the tutorials ofcourse). I am using node.js and a Postgres hosted in SAP BTP. 

I stated with the template build, completed multiple rounds of built and testing, ran locally with CDS watch and the application worked as expected. However, when I am trying to deploy this into CF, the postgres deployer task fails with an error message as shown below.

[PollExecuteTaskStatusExecution] 3af87674-613b-43f9-9eac-41c209b72ae7 [2025-11-24T05:12:22.793155] Error: Dropping tables is not supported (in artifact:“my.bookshop.Books”) (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-to-postgresql)#

I am not using this table. This looks like from the bookshop tutorial. I have checked extensively and nowhere in the source code there is any reference to this table. 

I thought this has remained from the SAP provided CAP application template (which I used to) and that template did use the bookshop data models. So, I recreated my app in a separate Dev space, and this time without using the CAP project template in BAS. I manually added the schema.cds, cat-services.cds. Added the package.json and mta.yaml files from the first iteration (checked them again for any reference to my.bookshop.Books reference).

But, I am still getting the same error. 

Then I created a test app to check all the tables in the postgres db. Did not find any table of this name. There was a table my_bookshop_Books in public schema. I deleted this one (I know it does not match in name, at this point I am out of ideas). No luck, I am still getting the same error.

Anyone knows what the issue could be? Where should I check and remove any reference to the my.bookshop.Books table?

Attached is the log file from the cloud foundry deployment process.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to set a different tolerance percentag...
entry.content:
Dear @Ahmed_Baiomy,

To clarify, it’s not possible to set tolerance at the package level within a strategy, this can only be configured at the plan level. As a result, when a call object associated with a package is completed, the deviation between the planned and actual completion dates is calculated at the plan level and therefore applies to all packages in that plan.

If tolerance needs to vary by package, the right approach is to split the strategy into multiple single-cycle plans and schedule each with the required tolerance. This will give you the control and accuracy you’re looking for.

Best regards,
Rohit
EAM Developer,  SAP Cloud ERP

It's important that the customers are aware of the fact that starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA  will be turned on by default, because that will have license implications for our customers, and we don't want them to have an unexpected surprise.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to set a different tolerance percentag...
entry.content:
Good day @Ahmed_Baiomy 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Maintenance Strategy, Maintenance Strategy/Maintenance Planning, Maintenance Package

In summary, the public cloud does not support per-package tolerances. Due to the clean-core principle, maintenance strategies support only one global tolerance in public cloud. You can meet your business need of different tolerance percentage, I recommend you split your single-entry strategy into multiple strategies or multiple maintenance plans.

As previously mentioned, the public cloud does not also allow you to use custom logic or BAdI to override tolerances.

Let me know if you have further question.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue Accessing Withholding Tax Configuration Apps in...
entry.content:
Dear @JuanseVal,

106626 and 105911 are country-specific SSCUIs, they are not generally deprecated, but only delivered for certain localizations like Spain/Indonesia in your case.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a8e130351783496f90c2750ef623bcb1/42b264b3ef6d4d7c9b76078c199d9c5d.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a624a4a6d1d8473eb95fb42660127cfe/8a14ce5541a649aeb919fa243fe7359e.html

IMPORTANT! If your project doesn’t include those countries, their absence is by design.

My environment has the country Spain but not Indonesia, so I don't see Business catalog: SAP_CA_BC_IC_LND_FIN_WT_ID_PC BUT I can see SAP_CA_BC_IC_LND_FIN_WT_ES_PC

I'll show you step-by-step what you need to do to gain access to the settings in CBC

In Public Cloud:

  • Open Maintain Business Role app
  • Search: SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT role
  • Edit and open tab Business Catalog, next click Add. You will find catalog for Spain

 

  • Apply and Save
  • Refresh SAP and CBC
  • Now you have access to Define Withholding Tax Keys Specific to the Country/Region (ID: 106626)

 

  • Repeat steps for Indonesia

You will find the countries assigned to your project below in CBC:

 

 Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Print Invoice Form for FI Customer Invoices in SAP S/...
entry.content:
Steps to print invoice PDF output for FI Customer Invoices has been documented in Printing of Customer Invoices in Financial Accounting (FI).

You can use the default form and email templates delivered by SAP or customize the templates as well as the output parameters according to your business needs. To set up the output for FI customer invoices, please see Configuring the Output of FI Customer Invoices.

Please note that, in order to retrieve this output, you need to create and post FI customer invoices directly via apps Create Outgoing Invoices (App ID FB70) or Upload Customer Open Items (App ID F4051).

entry.content:
Good day @P00019191 

Thank you for your question.

To answer your question, no they are not available as you intend.

In summary, as you have displayed on your screenshot, the SOAP API BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_In does not expose the Tax Type or Tax Number Type fields shown in the customer master Tax Data tab. That API only supports generic BP tax numbers but not localisation-specific tax fields.

The system does not currently provide you the option to access them through standard inbound API. You can only maintain them manually or through Master Data Governance.

I recommend you use OData A_BusinessPartner (V2) API to expose some additional tax structures. Note, that it will still exclude many localisation-specific fields.

You may also consider requesting an enhancement through the influence page from SAP.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Business Partner - Replicate from Client, Master Data Governance for Financials, Business Partner (A2X) – OData API

Let me know if you have further question.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP changed the certification strategy… Now what?
entry.content:
With the launch of its reimagined certification model, SAP has shifted away from traditional, theory-heavy training and embraced practical, scenario-based learning. The goal? To help learners apply skills directly to real-world roles across the SAP ecosystem.

This transformation doesn’t just apply to online courses, but it’s reshaping programs like the SAP Young Professionals and the SAP Dual Study. But new formats come with new challenges, especially around engagement. So, how do you keep learners truly connected, motivated, and mindful in a virtual environment?

To find out, we spoke with Professor David Felix, a SAP Young Professional and SAP Dual Study instructor known for turning remote sessions into high-energy, collaborative, and psychologically safe learning experiences. His approach blends playfulness, structure, and real SAP tools to deliver more than just knowledge; he fosters educational innovation.

How do you successfully manage a remote team?

“Start by understanding who’s in the room, not just what you're going to teach.” David Felix

Effective remote team management begins with empathy and psychological safety. Professor Felix opens sessions with music to set a relaxed tone and encourages open questions, reminding learners that no question is too simple. He recommends investing time upfront to understand participants’ concerns, expectations, and backgrounds. This allows instructors (or managers) to personalize their approach and treat learners as equals, creating a sense of accountability and shared responsibility.

What are the challenges of managing a remote team?

Remote environments come with natural barriers such as camera fatigue, lack of participation, and uneven engagement.

  • Some participants may log in but mentally check out.
  • Others may be too shy to speak or uncomfortable turning on their camera.
  • And not everyone will be equally motivated, and that’s okay.

David’s advice? Focus your energy on those who are actively present, without excluding others. Create a welcoming space, but don't waste energy trying to force engagement from those not ready.

What undermines trust on a remote team?

Trust fades when learners feel they can’t speak up, ask questions, or make mistakes.

That’s why David emphasizes building an emotionally safe learning space. He uses tools like a random roulette wheel to call on participants playfully, not to embarrass, but to create shared attention. Every interaction is framed as inclusive, informal, and non-judgmental.

What are some creative ways to boost morale in virtual teams?

Engagement must go beyond PowerPoints. During his sessions, David introduces:

  • Soundtracks to energize or relax, depending on the moment.
  • Roulette-based Q&A, where names are picked at random to add fun and unpredictability.
  • Magic tricks and playing cards, used as metaphors and attention hooks in sessions.
  • Live note-taking and diagramming to keep minds active and information digestible.

Especially after breaks or lunch, he uses disruptive elements to re-engage attention, such as a surprise quiz, puzzle, or visual challenge.

*Even when window washers suddenly appeared outside the training room, the learners stayed focused, fully engaged in the interactive session thanks to David's creative teaching style. His use of magic and humor captures attention and keeps energy high, no matter what’s happening around.*

 

How do you keep remote employees engaged and motivated?

The redesigned SAP YPP now emphasizes realistic scenarios, integrating topics across:

  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP SuccessFactors Platform 
  •  SAP Ariba Procurement 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, within others. 

This helps learners understand how SAP solutions connect departments in real business environments, not in isolated silos.

David enhances this through:

  • Writing live on slides to co-build knowledge
  • Avoiding static slides, which encourage passivity
  • Creating diagrams that show how SAP modules integrate across workflows, such as the ones below 👇

He also emphasizes the importance of frequent breaks and mental space, recognizing the limits of online attention spans. Engagement, he says, is a mutual commitment.

Why Mindfulness Matters in Remote Learning?

For the Digital Skills Center, mindfulness is both individual and systemic. Learners benefit from not having to commute but must create clear boundaries between work and rest to avoid burnout.

Learners are encouraged to: set up a dedicated learning space at home, decompress after sessions, use self-reflection time to synthesize information and prepare for the next step.

Even the closure of each class is designed mindfully summarizing progress, clarifying next steps, and keeping momentum going.

If you want to explore the SAP Young Professionals program to experience this blended learning journey, keep an eye on Digital Skills Center | SAP MENA, as cohorts are open on the rolling basis per country.

entry.title: Three "hidden" features in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud continues to evolve as a leading platform for analytics, planning and intelligent insights. Yet many users are unaware of the rich set of „hidden“ capabilities that sit beyond the standard functionality. These lesser known features offer meaningful advantages: from improving user experience to simplifying complex workflows. This blog highlights some of SAP Analytics Cloud’s most valuable but often overlooked tools that can significantly enhance how organizations interact with their data.

 

FEATURE 1 - BOOKMARKS

What are Bookmarks in SAP Analytics Cloud?

A Bookmark is a saved state of a story or page. It captures how the page looks at that moment, including – filters you selected, input controls, variable selections, drill levels etc. it’s like taking a snapshot of your story/page settings and not the data itself.

Why are Bookmarks useful?

  • Quickly return to your preferred view – if the story is complex, with many filters and drilldowns, you can setup a view once and refer back to it as needed.
  • Shre personalized views with others – you can create a bookmark and share it with specific users. Each user still has the latest live data not a static snapshot of the data.
  • Reduce user errors – instead of another user trying to recreate the view you have created, you can simply send them a bookmark and they view exactly what you see.

Steps to create a Bookmark:

In View mode: you can Bookmark the current state of a story to quickly return to it. Simply go to

The following screen will open:

You can enter a name and click on Save. Once saved you can check under Open Saved Bookmarks:

This will open the version you’ve bookmarked in View mode, you can still go into Edit mode and edit the bookmarked screen.

 

FEATURE 2 – SMART INSIGHTS

What are Smart Insights?

Smart Insights is an AI powered feature in SAP Analytics Cloud that can save time instead of manually creating reports to quickly view specific data. It helps non-technical users understand data – people who aren't analysts can instantly get a view of the data that they need without having to build a report.

Why are Smart Insights useful?

  • Supports faster decision making – Smart Insights turns raw data into actionable insights.
  • Easy access of information – can quickly check sales for a specific location within your data.

Steps to use Smart Insights:

From Home you can access Smart Insights (Just Ask)

You can also access Smart Insights from

This can be accessed from anywhere in SAP Analytics Cloud as it is pinned to the Toolbar area of SAP Analytics Cloud.

After clicking on the Smart Insights icon you will be taken to this screen:

Click on the “Indexed Acquired Models” dropdown and select your model:

Once you have selected your model, you can start selecting fields from the model you want to see. In this example I will look at Quantity Sold and Location:

Hit enter or click the blue lightbulb and SAP Analytics Cloud will start creating the visualizations for you:

P.S: This can also be viewed as a table and Data Analyzer can be accessed as well.

 

FEATURE 3: COMMENTS AND COLLABORATION

What are Comments in SAP Analytics Cloud?

Comments let you add notes, explanations, discussions or action items directly inside a story or dashboard. It's basically in-story communication, so people don’t need to leave SAP Analytics Cloud to discuss the data.

Why are Comments useful?

  • Keeps conversations in one place – with Comments, the discussion stays right next to the actual data, no context gets lost and no emails need to be sent.
  • Improves collaboration – teams can: ask questions, tag people, provide explanations etc, all directly in the dashboard. It turns dashboards into collaborative tools.
  • Useful for audit trails – Comments create a record of: decisions, discussions, explanations etc. if there is a question on the data months after a decision has been made; there us a clear trail to follow.

Steps to create Comments:

Click on the  in the Toolbar, go to Others and Click on Comment:

Below the Table you will see a Comment Widget loading and appear:

Click on “Click to add Comment”:

 To add in another comment after this click on the comment icon and another comment section will open:

As organizations aim to make more informed, timely decisions, understanding the full breadth of SAP Analytics Cloud’s capabilities becomes increasingly important. The “hidden” features discussed in this blog demonstrate how much more the platform can offer beyond the basics. By integrating these functionalities into your everyday processes, you can create more efficient workflows, more interactive stories and ultimately more impactful analytics. Leveraging these tools ensures you are getting the most out of your SAP Analytics Cloud investment.

entry.title: Harmonization of Authentication and Identity Management in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite
entry.content:
Introducing Harmonization of Authentication & Identity Management for SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite

As businesses evolve, so do their needs for even more robust security solutions and streamlined user management. Recognizing these demands, SAP Signavio is excited to announce a change to our authentication and identity capabilities of SAP Signavio. The rollout of the new capabilities will be in waves starting in 2025 and to be continued in 2026 and beyond to ensure you benefit from the enhancements from early on. The first wave only affects customers with new workspaces.

What’s changing when moving to our new authentication and identity capabilities of SAP Signavio

To deliver best-in-class security and simplified administrative layer of your SAP solutions, we are replacing and upgrading our existing capabilities through integration with SAP Cloud Identity (SCI) services in a phased approach endling with in a unified approach to managing identities and safeguarding access within the entire SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite.

Benefits at a Glance:

  • Unified User Management: The integration provides a centralized solution for handling administrative tasks related to user management. This means easier, more streamlined processes for admins and reduced complexity even as your organization scales.
  • Enterprise-Level Security and Compliance: Security is paramount in every organization. Our upgraded system offers robust, enterprise-level security features ensuring compliance with industry standards.
  • SSO and MFA Support: Out-of-the-box support for Single Sign-On (SSO) and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is now available. This upgrade simplifies access management, enhances security, and ensures seamless and secure authentication processes for users.
  • Rich Reporting and Audit Capabilities: Keeping track becomes a breeze with the ability to export user and group assignments data. Our self-service audit trails provide transparency in changes to group assignments and personal user data.
  • Directory Integration: We facilitate integration with corporate user directories like Microsoft Entra ID as a source system. Synchronize users and groups effortlessly via the SCIM protocol/connectors, ensuring all your identities are updated and unified.

A foundation for future innovations:

The harmonization is not just an upgrade. It’s laying the foundation for future advancements in identity management. Our pathway to solving long-standing customer feature requests becomes clearer, promising significant enhancements that meet your evolving needs.

Enhancements in role and access management:

This initiative also acts as a catalyst for substantial improvements in Role and Access Management. Expect better fine-grained access control, more detailed reporting, and stronger separation of duties, enabling your organization to efficiently dictate who gets access to what, while maintaining organizational integrity and security standards.

Roll-out in a phased approach:

The first phase, arriving late in 2025, marks the beginning of an exciting journey toward a simpler, even more secure identity experience. With this first wave, customers with new workspaces can immediately benefit from core SAP Cloud Identity (IAS) capabilities: enforce Single Sign-On (SSO) for new workspaces, enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), and rely on automatic syncing of user attributes and group assignments at login. These capabilities help organizations strengthen security and streamline access for users, while keeping their existing provisioning approach unchanged for now.

 What’s in and what is next?

Most importantly, this milestone is just the start, paving the way for upcoming improvements that will give administrators powerful tools for centralized user lifecycle management, further reducing manual work and enabling a truly integrated identity experience.

The Harmonization of Authentication and Identity Management marks an important step forward for SAP Signavio. As we continue to innovate and respond to your needs, our commitment remains to deliver advanced tools that secure, simplify, and enhance your operations.

Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements as we build on this foundational upgrade.

For any queries or further information, don't hesitate to reach out to our support team. We're here to assist you in making the most of these new features and safeguarding your digital enterprise.

entry.title: Re: How to Configure Local Currency and Thresholds in KPI...
entry.content:
Good day @JuanseVal 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage KPIs and Reports, Custom Analytical Queries, SAP Smart Business Modeler Apps, Configuring the Title Area

Check out this Blog: SAP BTP Developer's Guide: Extending Fiori Elements with the Flexible Programming Model

In summary, the public cloud does not allow you to change the currency of a standard KPI because it is defined in the underlying Analytical Query. However, you can display KPIs in COP or any other currency by copying the query, then expose the correct currency measure and build a custom KPI.

Regarding you question on Thresholds, you can maintain them in Manage KPIs and Reports --> Evaluation --> Target & Thresholds.

It works for custom KPIs and for standard KPIS only if permitted. If the evaluation is locked, I suggest you copy the KPI and create your own evaluation.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Streamline Supplier Onboarding in Ariba SLP: Reduce Friction, Cut Cycle Time, and Measure Success
entry.content:
Supplier onboarding on Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP) within the SAP Business Network is often the first meaningful interaction suppliers have with your procurement ecosystem. A smooth onboarding experience reduces manual work, speeds time-to-value, and improves supplier relationships.

In this post I want to cover common supplier challenges, buyer-side actions helping to shorten cycle time, and some of the KPIs to be tracked by procurement teams providing better visibility into the process. 

Common supplier pain points

Buyer organizations often observe their suppliers struggling with their SAP Business Network registrations, when accessing it for the first time. 

  • Registration confusion: suppliers are uncertain whether their organization already exists on the SAP Business Network (BN) or which link to use to register.
  • Missing administrators: suppliers don’t know who their BN company account administrator is and try to register new accounts.
  • Duplicate accounts: suppliers create new accounts believing their organization isn’t present, causing activations being blocked. 
  • Forgotten credentials: password resets and account recovery add delays and confusion.
  • Hard-to-navigate BN UI: suppliers struggle to find questionnaires, documents, or required pages.
  • Incomplete questionnaires: required fields or attachments are missed, causing rework.

 

What buying organizations can do (practical options)

What suppliers see during the onboarding is mostly controlled by the Buyers . Better design and support from buyers helps to reduce supplier drop-off and errors.

  1. Proactive discovery and outreach
    Query BN data to detect suppliers already present and send a branded email linking to their organization with a single call-to-action and a short checklist, expected timeline and contact for help.

    If an organization exists on the BN, present a “we found your organization — confirm this is you” option instead of forcing a fresh registration. Provide clear steps for finding or assigning the BN administrator.

  2. Direct invites and pre-population
    Issue SLP onboarding invitations that pre-fill known fields (company name, tax ID, address), so suppliers only confirm or correct values,  and link directly to the exact questionnaire page.

  3. Map administrators and publish escalation paths
    Maintain a directory of supplier admin contacts. If unknown, require admin confirmation during outreach and provide a buyer-side escalation contact with a published SLA (e.g., respond within 24 business hours).

  4. Prevent duplicate accounts
    Add a “how to search for your organization” guide (screenshots) in outreach. If duplicates appear, pause onboarding workflows and assist with merging or linking accounts.

    Use VAT, DUNS, or registration-number matching during invite and submission. When a match is found, offer the supplier options to claim, request a merge, or request buyer assistance rather than blocking them.

  5. Make password recovery obvious and fast
    Include password-reset links in invites and onboarding emails, plus a short FAQ and a time-limited chat/phone support window for account issues.

  6. Simplify questionnaires & UI guidance
    Keep questionnaires minimal and use conditional fields to hide irrelevant questions. Provide field-level hints, acceptable file types, and a 2–3 minute walkthrough video showing where to find forms and how to upload documents.

  7. Use validations and automated checks
    Enable SLP format validations (VAT/tax ID, bank account patterns) and implement automated acceptance rules to fast-track suppliers meeting baseline criteria.

  8. Offer dedicated support & fast-track channels
    Run onboarding clinics (live and recorded) and provide “concierge” onboarding for strategic suppliers.
    Route complex or high-risk cases to a verification team with committed response times (e.g., 24–48 hours), and notify suppliers about expected timelines.

  9. Internal governance & training
    Define owner roles, SLAs for response/activation, and train procurement, master-data, and supplier enablement teams on SLP workflows and common supplier issues.

Practical messaging examples

Customizing invitation emails, or sending your own personalized invitations before slicking "INVITE" button in the application can set up the tone of the registration procedure and contribute to smoother interactions of suppliers with the "new system". Sample invitation message may contain the following elements:

Invite subject: “Action required: Complete your registration to transact with [BuyerName] on SAP Business Network”

Email body: link to organization page, estimated time (10–15 minutes), checklist (admin contact, VAT, banking, certificates), link to 2-minute walkthrough, and buyer support email + SLA.

Troubleshooting snippet: “Can’t find your company? Search by registration number. Still not found — reply to this email and our team will assist.”

 

KPIs to track (what to measure and why)

KPIs show you what's actually working (or not). Providing help with identifying bottlenecks they can help you to focus on areas needing fixes. Without them, organizations are effectively flying blind.

  • Invite open rate — % of invites opened. Low values point to delivery or messaging issues. Measure via email analytics weekly.
  • Time to Onboard (median & 95th percentile) — time from invite/request to Active status; track median and 95th percentile; aim to reduce it.
  • First-pass Completion Rate — % of registrations accepted without rework; indicates questionnaire clarity.
  • Duplicate Account Rate — % of onboardings that create duplicates requiring merge; high rates signal discovery or invite targeting issues.
  • Supplier Admin Identified Rate — % of suppliers that verify an administrator within SLA; critical for handoffs.
  • Support contacts per 100 suppliers — help tickets/calls during onboarding; indicates need for clearer guidance or UI fixes.
  • Support Ticket Volume & SLA Compliance — onboarding-related tickets and percent resolved within target SLA.
  • Questionnaire Completion Quality Score — composite score of completeness, document validity, and correct formats.
  • Drop-off Rate by Step (funnel) — % who start but do not complete each stage (invite → start → upload docs → submit → activate).
  • Supplier satisfaction (post-onboarding) — short survey (1–2 questions) in the welcome email to capture qualitative feedback.

Suggested targets (this is an example, adjust for your own situation):

  • Invite open rate: >60%
  • Questionnaire completion: >70% within 7 days
  • Median time to activation: <7 days for standard suppliers; <48 hours for low-risk
  • Duplicate rate: <3%
  • Support tickets per 100 suppliers: <5

 

Quick wins (first 30 days)

  • Send a standardized invite with checklist and direct links.
  • Trim questionnaires to essentials and add conditional fields.
  • Publish a short “How to register” walkthrough with screenshots.
  • Set and communicate a 24–48 hour SLA for onboarding support.
  • Start tracking Time to Onboard and First-pass Completion Rate.

 

90-day program (roadmap)

  1. Month 1: Implement quick wins and set up KPI dashboards (Time to Onboard, First-pass Completion).
  2. Month 2: Run onboarding clinics, enable pre-fill invites, and add automated validation rules.
  3. Month 3: Analyze funnel drop-offs, refine questionnaires, offer concierge onboarding for strategic suppliers, and report improvements to stakeholders.

Key takeaways

  • Prioritize removing manual steps, pre-populating known data, and providing clear, actionable guidance to suppliers.
  • Measure both speed (Time to Onboard) and quality (First-pass Completion, Duplicate Account Rate, questionnaire quality).
  • Combine proactive outreach, streamlined forms, automated validations, user guidance, and a defined support SLA to minimize rework and shorten cycle time.

entry.title: Read Confirmation in SAP Signavio – How to Automate It with SAP Signavio Process Governance
entry.content:
Read Confirmation is a simple yet highly relevant governance requirement in many organizations:
Employees must confirm that they have read and understood a procedure, policy, or process update.

In SAP Signavio, there are two ways to handle read confirmations – the built-in capability in SAP Signavio Process Manager, and a fully customizable approach using SAP Signavio Process Governance (SPG).
In this blog post, I will show both options and then focus on how you can build a flexible, automated, and auditable read-confirmation workflow using Process Governance.

Why Read Confirmation Matters

Organizations face a variety of regulatory, compliance, and operational demands — whether in procurement, finance, HR, operations, or IT.
Ensuring that employees not only receive process updates but also acknowledge and understand them is essential for:

  • Compliance & audit readiness

  • Reducing operational risk

  • Increasing process transparency

  • Ensuring consistent process execution

Option 1: Standard Read Confirmation in SAP Signavio Process Manager

SAP Signavio Process Manager provides a standard feature to collect read confirmations directly on diagram level.

You can assign:

  • A single user

  • Multiple users

  • A user group

  • Multiple user groups

The confirmation status is displayed in the diagram header, and you can export the confirmation list if needed.

 

This option works well for simple use cases.
However, many customers require more advanced logic such as:

  • Automatically requesting confirmation for all “Procurement processes” by all “Buyers”

  • Running confirmations after every approval workflow

  • Storing results in a central, tabular report

  • Triggering reminders or escalations

  • Displaying confirmation status directly in the Collaboration Hub

This is where SAP Signavio Process Governance becomes extremely powerful.

Option 2: Fully Customizable Read Confirmations with SAP Signavio Process Governance

SAP Signavio Process Governance allows organizations to automate governance activities across the entire process lifecycle.
These include among many others moving models, updating dictionary items, archiving, model health checks, ownership transfers, publishing/ unpublishing workflows, BPMN exports, document creation, and much more.
(See the official capabilities described in the Feature Scope Description and User Guide .)

Among these use cases, Read Confirmation stands out as one of the simplest to configure, yet one of the most impactful.

Scenario: Read Confirmation Automatically After a Process Approval Workflow

In this example, we enhance an existing BPMN approval workflow so that after the diagram is approved a read confirmation is automatically sent to a specific user group.
The confirmation will say: “I have read and understood the BPMN.”
The result will be visible in the SAP Signavio Collaboration Hub, and you can export all confirmations via SPG Analytics.

Step-by-Step Configuration

Step 1: Copy or Import Your Existing Approval Workflow

Open SAP Signavio SAP Signavio Process Governance and simply copy an existing approval workflow template.

To avoid changing the original workflow, I downloaded it, renamed it, and uploaded it again as a separate version.

 

Step 2: Add a Read Confirmation Step

After the final approval event, add a User Task to the workflow.

Inside the form builder, add a Yes/No checkbox with the label:

“I understood and read the BPMN!”

This becomes the mandatory confirmation.

 

Step 3: Define the Recipients (General Tab)

Under General, select who must confirm the reading —
for example:

  • A specific user

  • A whole user group

  • One or multiple departments

This allows automated role-based governance.

Step 4: Configure Reminders (Optional)

If employees forget to confirm, automated reminders can be configured directly in the task settings.

Reminders help enforce compliance without manual follow-up.

 

Step 5: Publish Your Workflow

Once published, this workflow is available and ready to execute.
Every time a process goes through approval, the read confirmation is triggered automatically.

 

Step 6: Use SPG Analytics for Reporting

Create a dedicated reporting area in Analytics to download CSV reports.
This gives you a tabular list of:

  • Who confirmed

  • When they confirmed

  • Which process

  • Status (open / completed)

     

     

Optional: This data can be exported or integrated via the Analytics API.

Step 7: Test the Workflow

Run a quick test to make sure:

  • The approval triggers the confirmation

  • The checkbox appears correctly

  • The confirmation is logged

  • The status displays in Collaboration Hub

  • Report data is captured as expected

  • We created a video for you to show the hole process 

Summary:

Read Confirmation is not just a checkbox it is a vital part of governance, compliance, and operational excellence.

While SAP Signavio  offers a simple built-in feature, SAP Signavio Process Governance allows you to design end-to-end, automated, and fully customized read-confirmation workflows that fit your organization's governance model.

The setup is straightforward far easier than most expect and offers huge value in ensuring accountability and compliance.

And because it seems mandatory to mention Artificial Intelligence everywhere these days, here is the official disclaimer:
This workflow can be fully built and executed without any AI at all 😉. 

At this point I want to thank @annika1998 for her consistent support! Check out her LinkedIn.
